Award.AwardTitle: Carbon nanotube detection in plants through microwave-induced heating

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1133250
Green

This NSF award by the Environmental Health and Safety of Nanotechnology program supports work by Professors Micah Green, Jaclyn Ca√±as, and Mohammad Saed of Texas Tech University to develop new methods to detect the presence of carbon nanotubes in agricultural crops. Carbon nanotubes are among the most widely used carbon-based nanomaterials, and one area of potential use for nanotubes is for the improvement and benefit of agricultural production, such as smart delivery systems for pesticides and other chemicals. The study of nanotube uptake into the roots of agricultural crops is a pressing issue; this is particularly true in regard to the industrial interest in utilizing nanotubes in agricultural pesticides and other products that might deposit nanotubes in soil.

However, common methods of detecting trace amounts of nanotubes in crops are limited. The Texas Tech
team will pioneer a new technique to detect these materials in crops by using low-power microwave exposure. Although this unusual property has been known for some time, it has never been utilized to solve scientific challenges in the area of environmental toxicology. Nanotubes undergo rapid heating in response to microwaves at levels much higher than other common materials. The Texas Tech team will test the hypothesis that microwave exposure will show a marked difference between nanotube-laden and nanotube-free agricultural samples.

The microwave-based characterization method is both novel and useful, as it addresses a major scientific problem in the field of nanotoxicology. This concept is enabled by the uniquely collaborative combination of expertise fielded by the PI and co-PIs in their respective areas of nanomaterials, toxicology, and microwave physics. Microwave heating of CNTs has never been used for detection before and has never been applied to the critical issue of nanotechnology?s environmental and agricultural effects. Thus, this program has the potential to have widespread impacts on safety and testing protocols for nanomaterial-based agricultural products in the U.S.

The outreach and diversity efforts of the program will place a particular emphasis on recruiting undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups and incorporating these students and their interdisciplinary research findings into educational outreach programs. These activities will augment and further disseminate successful K-12 educational programs initiated by the PI and co-PIs under prior NSF awards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While carbon nanotubes (CNTs) show tremendous promise for advanced materials, concerns have been raised regarding the implications of this emerging technology.  One area of potential use for CNTs is the improvement and benefit of agricultural production, such as smart delivery systems for pesticides and other chemicals.  The study of CNT uptake into agricultural crops and related organisms is a pressing issue because of the industrial interest in utilizing CNTs in agricultural pesticides and other products. However, common methods of detecting trace amounts of CNTs suffer from practical difficulties that limit their usefulness. Thus, the development of a novel method for CNT detection helped us to assess movement of CNTs in plants to evaluate food safety. Our method utilizes the unique microwave response of CNTs as a metric for CNT content. Figure 1 shows our experimental setup; the powdered sample is placed inside an ampoule, which is exposed to low-power, precise microwaves at the quarter-wavelength of a custom waveguide (connected to a solid-state microwave source). The temperature rise (as measured by thermocouple or fiber optic) is directly correlated with the CNT content in the sample mass.

Given the success of this method, we carried out the following toxicology studies: CNTs were taken up by plant roots and moved by the plant to above ground portions of the plant (Figure 2). However, further studies are needed to identify if CNTs are taken up into edible portions of plants.

The widespread use of CNTs increases the chances of contamination of aquatic environments. This study also included an assessment of the movement of CNTs in an aquatic food chain. CNTs were taken up by Daphnia magna (water fleas) and then transferred to fathead minnow through consumption of contaminated D. magna (Figure 3). Further studies are needed to determine if CNTs are taken up into edible portions of the fish to protect human health.

This study was conducted by an interdisciplinary team (toxicologist, chemical engineer, and electrical engineer) and has involved several graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering, including minorities and females. Findings from this study will help to provide much needed information regarding the environmental implications of carbon nanotube nanomaterials and be of use to a wide variety of scientists from toxicologists to material scientists to those charged with establishing policies regarding nanomaterials.
